text: my name's Andrew D'Souza I'm the
co-founder and CEO of clear bank
we provide financing for startups and
founders to grow their business and
acquire their customers without giving
up equity in their business the
structured as a revenue share agreement
so we look into business's fundamental
metrics how efficiently they're
acquiring customers how much they're
scaling and and how scalable that
revenue is and we take a fixed share of
their daily sales until we get our money
back plus a six percent fee so we
started by doing a lot of e-commerce
companies so funding companies that are
acquiring customers online through
channels like Facebook and Google
they've got to be doing probably about
10,000 dollars of sales minimum on a
monthly basis and up to our largest
companies are doing five hundred million
so pretty wide range we just ingest all
the data we're able to make them an
offer instantly we just launched a
product called the 20 minute term sheet
which we actually launched on AWS which
is great the idea is you know instead of
founders having to get on planes and
pitch their business you know give us
access to data we pitched you on you
know why you should capitalize your
company in this way and can get started
really quickly you know we want those
companies to grow and take more capital
and pay us back faster so we can deploy
more capital to them and whatever we can
do to help them grow that's our that's
our business model
fund-raising can be a huge huge time
sink for founder's and I actually spend
a lot of my career helping founders you
know go through the fundraising process
and meet the investors that that they
needed to and I think realized very
quickly that one of the big challenges
it's a very opaque process if you didn't
go to the right schools and you don't
have the right pedigree or network you
can't even get your foot in the door and
then once you get your foot in the door
you've got to take three months at least
stop running your business to go
fundraise and most companies can't
afford their founders to do that and
then finally you know equity is a really
expensive way to capitalize right you
give up control off in you know you give
up a board seat and equities is
expensive if your company's growing and
so we decided to do was create a you
know more repeatable scalable way to
help companies grow we're funding
repeatable growth so $1 in today equals
$4 in 12 months we can fund that on a
revenue share and we get paid back as
that revenue materializes and I think
that's where you know a lot of high
growth online businesses that's where
they're spending with the majority of
their budgets and we can actually step
in and fund that more efficiently than
equity or debt
this year you know it's about global
expansion and diversifying you know
we've started in e-commerce we're
diversifying away from just e-commerce
and funding any business that has
repeatable unit economics and we're
starting to look at that globally you
know over over the next 5-10 years I
think the idea is can we actually shift
the power dynamic can we shift the power
back to founders and entrepreneurs and
away from the capital markets and
investors have sort of held held that
power for the last like you know several
centuries and I think you know the way
we'll know that we've won is we see the
next wave of exits and IPOs and people
look back and be like I'll remember
those 2019 IPOs with a founder zone like
single-digit percentage of the business
like that was a crazy time now we can
really you know control our destiny and
own you know own more of the business
and whether that is I just want to run
this forever and I want to dividend it
out and I want to you know hand it over
to my kids or I want to IPO it or I want
to sell it I have that power I don't I'm
you know I'm not at the behest of my
investors on my board I can actually
write my own destiny and build the type
of business that I want to yeah AWS has
been has been great for us being able to
stand up new products we manage a ton of
data and being able to do that in a
secure way and in an efficient way what
a great example is we launched this
product called the 20 minute term sheet
which is essentially sort of you know if
you think about the term sheet is as
what founders spend months of their
lives pitching investors to try and get
this piece of paper we figured out a way
to do that in 20 minutes and the cool
thing was you know our director of
marketing he coded the entire thing up
built on today WS spun it up in like a
couple weeks which we wouldn't either
would have never been able to do using
any other sort of infrastructure so that
was a really cool cool example of how
AWS has helped us
